bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Rupert Blue, September 14, 1918

div1.p: Carter discusses the outbreak of dengue fever in Galveston, Texas.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Rupert Blue, September 14, 1918
div1.opener:
Dengue.in Galveston, Texas.
Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter.
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
Misc
Dengue
Galveston
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
Galveston, Texas.
September 14, 1918.
The Surgeon General,
U.S. Public Health Service,
Washington, D. C.
Sir:-
div1.p:
I have the honor to state that a reference to his case book by
Dr. Gammon, office next door to this one, shows that he treated three cases
of dengue all in one family, corner 15th and Market Streets, all adults,
on August 13th.

There is a case probably of dengue, but not so recognised at the
time, treated by Dr. Singleton not later than August 10th.

The period of incubation of four experimental cases conveyed by
Aedes calupus (Stegamyia) is given as from 5 to 9 days by Cleland and Bradley.
I have not the paper with me but it was published in the Journal of Hygiene
(Nuttall's Journal) last spring and is fairly convincing, work done in
Australia.

If we accept the period of incubation given, 5 to 9 days, it
seems improbable that 3 cases in one family would have arisen as early
as August 13th, from infection introduced by infected man on August 5th.
It would allow only 3 days for the extringic incubation in the mosquito,
assuming the disease is only so conveyed. Although there are no observations
to show this period of extringic incubation, unless one accept Craig's two
days period in Cules fat, yet from the analogy of other host borne diseases
it seems extremely short.

I am no longer investigating Dengue but this data may be of in-
terest to you.

I was hoing to Houston today on my own initiative to see if I
could be of use to Dr. Holt, but am awaiting the orders promised in your
telegram of September 13, 1918, received last night.
